Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Gloria M. Coruzzi (New York University)

CoPIs: Robert DeSalle (American Museum Natural History), W. Richard McCombie (Cold Spring Harbor Laboratories), Dennis E. Shasha (New York University), and Dennis W. Stevenson (New York Botanical Garden)

Senior Personnel: Eric Brenner (New York Botanical Garden), Manpreet Katari (New York University), Ernest Lee (American Museum of Natural History), and Robert Martienssen (Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory)

The goal of this project is to exploit plant genome diversity to discover new genes involved in the development of seeds. This project combines the expertise of scientists from four research/educational institutions specializing in evolution and genomics to build upon a previously funded pilot project to generate new data, resources, and bioinformatic tools and analytical pipelines to enable functional trait-to-gene predictions for any species based on phylogeny and/or machine learning approaches. It is envisioned that the data and software resources generated will empower Comparative Genomic researchers to exploit plant diversity to identify genes associated with any trait of interest or economic value. All sequence data will be available at GenBank and all germplasm through the New York Botanical Gardens. In addition, the public can access data, tools, and resources generated from this project at the following links: OrthologID (http://nypg.bio.nyu.edu/orthologid), BIGPLANTv1 (http://nypg.bio.nyu.edu/orthologid/bigplant) and ViCoGenTA (http://nypg.bio.nyu.edu/vicogenta).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF-PGRP funded “Genomics of Comparative Seed Evolution” project is working to identify genes that are important in the evolution and development of seeds.  Because life on earth depends on plants, our need for seed derived products is inherent to human existence. From food to clothing, seeds are fundamental. With the diminishing availability of arable land, understanding how seeds develop can be aided by determining how seeds have evolved, particularly at the genomic level. Hence, we used a comparative approach to identify the genes that support the divergence of the seedless land plants  -  from the genomes of the most primitive living seed plants (gymnosperms), and the modern seed plants (angiosperms).  The angiosperms include the model developmental systems such as Arabidopsis and rice which serve as reference genomes of partially understood function. This comparative phylogenomic approach will enable us identify the genes that enabled seeds to evolve in the gymnosperms  (which have survived since the mesosoic era) - to further our understanding of seed development, which ultimately can be tested for improving crop systems and yields.

We generated the first broad set of gene sequence data for the Gymnosperms, the earliest seed plants, including some species in this poorly studied branch of the tree of life that have never before been sampled at the genomic level. The availability of this genetic information will serve as the first step towards understanding the genomic adaptations that co-occurred with and potentially caused the appearance of seeds in the primitive gymnosperms. The first genetic regulatory programs to give rise to seeds and package them with rich nutrients have originated in these primitive plants and we now have means to explore these genes. Our second goal in this project was to develop the informatic methods and tools that can process the information from thousands of genes discovered in each species and make sense out of their evolutionary relationship to the observed traits in the plant. Each plant genome contains tens of thousands of genes and we need powerful algorithms to compare and contrast these gene sets. One biologically meaningful way to do this is to analyze the genes in the context of their evolutionary history, which allows us to associate the origin and changes in gene sequences to the occurrence of observed traits in the organism. To do this, we developed a powerful phylogenomic pipeline called BigPlant that can analyze the complete gene sets from hundreds of plant species to reconstruct the complete evolutionary history of these species from this very large (hence very reliable) data set. The special property of the BigPlant phylogenomic pipeline is that in addition to the phylogeny reconstruction, it has the unique power to determine the set of genes that specifically support the divergence of two related but distinct species or groups of species. Therefore, we can use this phylogenomic pipeline to identify the set genes that are most relevant to a trait that has evolved within a group of species. For example, we used this phylogenomic pipeline to identify a set of 100 genes that are relevant to the ability of plants to form a highly beneficial symbiosis with soil fungi. This plant-fungal sysmbiosis greatly increases the plant’s ability to acquire water and nutrients from the soil. The BigPlant phylogenomic pipeline is built for a very large datasets and generates valuable information about the evolutionary history of each plant gene. As a result, the outcome of the pipeline is complex and difficult to parse. To make such datasets readily accessible to individual researchers interested in specific genes we developed a highly interactive visualization tool called PhyloBrowse, to display the phylogenomic outcomes generated by BigPlant.
